social.author: Orson Welles

social.quote: It's not true that life is one damn thing after another; it is one damn thing over and over.
social.author: Edna St. Vincent Millay

social.quote: The mass of men live lives of quiet exasperation.
social.author: Phyllis McGinley

social.quote: There will always be something to ruin our lives, it all depends on what or which finds us first. We are always ripe and ready to be taken.
social.author: Charles Bukowski

social.quote: To great evils we submit; we resent little provocations.
social.author: William Hazlitt

social.quote: How little it takes to make life unbearable ... a pebble in the shoe, a cockroach in the spaghetti, a woman's laugh.
social.author: H. L. Mencken

social.quote: No tyranny is so irksome as petty tyranny: the officious demands of policemen, government clerks, and electromechanical gadgets.
social.author: Edward Abbey

social.quote: Treat all disasters as if they were trivialities but never treat a triviality as if it were a disaster.
social.author: Quentin Crisp

social.quote: Men often bear little grievances with less courage than they do large misfortunes.
social.author: Aesop

social.quote: It is usually not so much the greatness of our trouble as the littleness of our spirit which makes us complain.
social.author: Jeremy Taylor

social.quote: All things work for good for those who love God. Romans 8:28. Not some things or most things but all things; so praise Him even in your troubles.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: In every trouble, there's a blessing.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: The more you talk about your troubles, the harder it is to find somebody who will listen.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: The really happy man is the one who can enjoy the scenery even when he has to take a detour.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: Nobody knows the trouble I've seen, Nobody knows but Jesus.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: The art of living lies less in eliminating our troubles than in growing with them.
social.author: Bernard Baruch

social.quote: Troubles are often the tools by which God fashions us for better things.
social.author: Henry Ward Beecher

social.quote: People need trouble-a little frustration to sharpen the spirit on, toughen it. Artists do, I don't mean you need to live in a rathole or gutter, but you do have to learn fortitude, endurance. Only vegetables are happy.
social.author: William Faulkner

social.quote: There is nothing more likely to start disagreement among people or countries than an agreement.
social.author: E. B. White

social.quote: Treaties are like roses and young girls. They last while they last.
social.author: Charles de Gaulle

social.quote: Let us never negotiate out of fear. But let us never fear to negotiate.
social.author: John F. Kennedy

social.quote: Peace does not rest in charters and covenants alone. It lies in the hearts and minds of the people.
social.author: John F. Kennedy

social.quote: Treaties are observed as long as they are in harmony with interests.
social.author: Napoleon I

social.quote: History is a pathetic junkyard of broken treaties.
social.author: Richard Nixon

social.quote: The only treaties that ought to count are those which would effect a settlement between ulterior motives.
social.author: Paul Valery

social.quote: I don't mind plain women being Puritans. It is the only excuse they have for being plain.
social.author: Oscar Wilde

social.quote: When the eye fails to find beauty-alias solace-it commands the body to create it, or, failing that, adjusts itself to perceive virtue in ugliness.
social.author: Joseph Brodsky

social.quote: The secret of ugliness consists not in irregularity, but in being uninteresting.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: Since our persons are not of our own making, when they are such as appear defective or uncomely, it is, methinks, an honest and laudable fortitude to dare to be ugly.
social.author: Richard Steele

social.quote: All uncertainty is fruitful ... so long as it is accompanied by the wish to understand.
social.author: Antonio Machado

social.quote: The appalling uncertainty of man's existence is haltingly underscored by the momentous certainty of the phenomenon of death.
social.author: William R. Tolbert, Jr.

social.quote: Doubt of the reality of love ends by making us doubt everything.
social.author: Henri Frederic Amiel

social.quote: We are not certain, we are never certain. If we were, we could reach some conclusions, and we could, at last, make others take us seriously.
social.author: Albert Camus

social.quote: Half the agony of living is waiting.
social.author: Alexander Rose

social.quote: How wonderful it is that nobody need wait a single moment before starting to improve the world.
social.author: Anne Frank

social.quote: Serene, I fold my hands and wait, Nor care for wind, nor tide, nor sea; I rave no more gainst time or fate, For lo! my own shall come to me.
social.author: John Burroughs

social.quote: How much of human life is lost in waiting!
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: The philosophy of waiting is sustained by all the oracles of the universe.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: They also serve who only stand and wait.
social.author: John Milton

social.quote: He (God) never comes to those who do not wait.
social.author: Frederick William Faber

social.quote: We wait always for something that does not come.
social.author: Ernest Hemingway

social.quote: Once a man would spend a week patiently waiting if he missed a stage coach, but now he rages if he misses the first section of a revolving door.
social.author: Simeon Strunsky

social.quote: If you are seeking creative ideas, go out walking. Angels whisper to a man when he goes for a walk.
social.author: Raymond Inmon

social.quote: We make the path by walking.
social.author: Robert Bly

social.quote: These feet have walked ten thousand miles working for white folks and another ten thousand keeping up with colored.
social.author: Langston Hughes

social.quote: People seem to think there is something inherently noble and virtuous in the desire to go for a walk.
social.author: Max Beerbohm

social.quote: A sedentary life is the real sin against the Holy Spirit. Only those thoughts that come by walking have any value.
social.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

social.quote: Road's in front o' me, Nothin' to do but walk.
social.author: Langston Hughes

social.quote: It is good walking when one hath his horse in hand.
social.author: John Lyly

social.quote: Walking is good for the soul.
social.author: Andrew A. Rooney

social.quote: Walking is the favorite sport of the good and wise.
social.author: A. L. Rowse

social.quote: The wall must go.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: People are lonely because they build walls instead of bridges.
social.author: Joseph Fort Newton

social.quote: ... maybe it is only by banging our heads against it that we can bring this accursed wall down.
social.author: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn

social.quote: If you don't get everything you want, think of the things you don't get that you don't want.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: Poverty wants some things, luxury many things, and avarice all things.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: I want, I want.
social.author: Saul Bellow

social.quote: Necessities are few, but our wants are endless.
social.author: Benjamin Franklin

social.quote: Constantly choose rather to want less, than to have more.
social.author: Thomas a Kempis

social.quote: I believe serious progress (in the abolition of war) can be achieved only when men become organized on an international scale and refuse, as a body, to enter military or war service.
social.author: Albert Einstein

social.quote: War lives on despotism and is not waged with God's love.
social.author: Simon Bolivar

social.quote: I don't know what will be used in the next world war, but the fourth will be fought with stones.
social.author: Albert Einstein

social.quote: I appeal to all men and women, whether they be eminent or humble, to declare that they will refuse to give any further assistance to war or the preparation of war.
social.author: Albert Einstein

social.quote: War determines not who is right but who is left.
social.author: Rabbi Sidney Greenberg

social.quote: Christianity has not failed. It is simply that nations have failed to try it. There would be no war in a God-directed world.
social.author: Admiral Richard E. Byrd

social.quote: To my mind, to kill in war is not a whit better than to commit ordinary murder.
social.author: Albert Einstein

social.quote: It is not merely cruelty that leads men to love war, it is excitement.
social.author: Henry Ward Beecher

social.quote: I believe all war to be wholly wrong.
social.author: Mahatma Gandhi

social.quote: Love of my country does not demand that I shall hate and slay those noble and faithful souls who also love theirs.
social.author: Romain Rolland

social.quote: All know that the drop merges into the ocean but few know that the ocean merges into the drop.
social.author: Kabir

social.quote: The old pond, ah! A frog jumps in: The water's sound.
social.author: Matsuo Basho

social.quote: Water, thou hast no taste, no color, no odor; canst not be defined, art relished while ever mysterious. Not necessary to life, but rather life itself, thou fillest us with a gratification that exceeds the delight of the senses.
social.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupery

social.quote: My life is like water that has passed the mill; it turns no wheel.
social.author: Thomas Wolfe

social.quote: A drowning man will catch at a straw.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: Vast is the mighty ocean, but drops have made it vast.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: God brings men into deep waters, not to drown them, but to cleanse them.
social.author: Aughey

social.quote: Water, water, everywhere, Nor any drop to drink.
social.author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge

social.quote: We never know the worth of water till the well is dry.
social.author: Thomas Fuller

social.quote: He who has access to the fountain does not go to the water-pot.
social.author: Leonardo da Vinci

social.quote: We have allowed a soft sentimentalism to form the atmosphere we breathe. And in that kind of atmosphere, a diffuse desire to do good has become a substitute for tough-minded plans and operations-a substitute for strategy.
social.author: John F. Kennedy

social.quote: The weak have one weapon: the errors of those who think they are strong.
social.author: Georges Bidault

social.quote: The weakest and most timorous are the most revengeful and implacable.
social.author: Thomas Fuller

social.quote: It was not the violence of our enemies [in World War I] that would undo us, I thought, but our own spiritual weakness, the shallowness of our convictions.
social.author: Learned Hand

social.quote: He is a fool who tries to match his strength with the stronger. He will lose his battle, and with the shame will be hurt also.
social.author: Hesiod

social.quote: It is to escape the responsibility for failure that the weak so eagerly throw themselves into grandiose undertakings.
social.author: Eric Hoffer

social.quote: We cannot win the weak by sharing our wealth with them. They feel our generosity as oppression.
social.author: Eric Hoffer

social.quote: Often we are firm from weakness, and audacious from timidity.
social.author: Francois de La Rochefoucauld

social.quote: There is nothing so imperious as feebleness which feels itself supported by force.
social.author: Napoleon I

social.quote: Willful waste brings woeful want.
social.author: Thomas Fuller

social.quote: Waste not, want not.
social.author: Thomas Hardy

social.quote: Extreme cold when it first arrives seems to generate cheerfulness and sociability. For a few hours all life's dubious problems are dropped in favor of the clear and congenial task of keeping alive.
social.author: E. B. White

social.quote: A cloudy day, or a little sunshine, have as great an influence on many constitutions as the most real blessings or misfortunes.
social.author: Joseph Addison

social.quote: There it is, fog, atmospheric moisture still uncertain in destination, not quite weather and not altogether mood, yet partaking of both.
social.author: Hal Borland

social.quote: The air was so damp that fish could have come in through the doors and swum out the windows, floating through the atmosphere in the rooms.
social.author: Gabriel Garcia Marquez

social.quote: For the man sound in body and serene of mind there is no such thing as bad weather; every sky has its beauty, and storms which whip the blood do but make it pulse more vigorously
social.author: George Gissing

social.quote: We shall never be content until each man makes his own weather and keeps it to himself.
social.author: Jerome K. Jerome

social.quote: Weather in towns is like a skylark in a counting-house-out of place and in the way.
social.author: Jerome K. Jerome

social.quote: Who knows whither the clouds have fled? In the unscarred heaven they leave no wake; And the eyes forget the tears they have shed, The heart forgets its sorrow and ache.
social.author: James Russell Lowell

social.quote: On the Continent there is one topic which should be avoided-the weather; in England, if you do not repeat the phrase "Lovely day, isn't it?" at least two hundred times a day, you are considered a bit dull.
social.author: George Mikes

social.quote: There is nothing more universally commended than a fine day; the reason is, that people can commend it without envy.
social.author: William Shenstone

social.quote: The dark threads are as needful in the Weaver's skillful hand, As the threads of gold and silver in the pattern He has planned.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: The pleasure of gratifying whim is very great. It is known only by those who are whimsical.
social.author: James Boswell

social.quote: The only difference between a caprice and a lifelong passion is that the caprice lasts a little longer.
social.author: Oscar Wilde

social.quote: If it were not for the presents, an elopement would be preferable.
social.author: George Ade

social.quote: Bride, n. A woman with a fine prospect of happiness behind her.
social.author: Ambrose Bierce

social.quote: Girls usually have a papier mache face on their wedding day.
social.author: Colette

social.quote: Weddings seem to be magnets for mishap and for whatever craziness lurks in family closets. In more ways than one, weddings bring out the ding-dong on everybody involved.
social.author: Robert Fulghum

social.quote: Let there be no more weddings. Get thee to a nunnery.
social.author: William Shakespeare

social.quote: At American weddings, the quality of the food is in inverse proportion to the social position of the bride and groom.
social.author: Calvin Trillin

social.quote: Wit makes its own welcome and levels all distinctions.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: Welcome each rebuff, That turns earth's smoothness rough, Each sting that bids nor sit nor stand but go!
social.author: Robert Browning

social.quote: Welcome, O life! I go to encounter for the millionth time the reality of experience and to forge in the smithy of my soul the uncreated conscience of my race.
social.author: James Joyce

social.quote: Welcome is the best cheer.
social.author: Thomas Fuller

social.quote: Welcome death, quoth the rat, when the trap fell.
social.author: Thomas Fuller

social.quote: Welcome thy neighbor into thy fallout shelter. He'll come in handy if you run out of food.
social.author: Dean McLaughlin

social.quote: Without the rich heart, wealth is an ugly beggar.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: To be poor without murmuring is difficult. To be rich without being proud is easy.
social.author: Confucius

social.quote: Natural wealth is limited and easily obtained; the wealth defined by vain fancies is always beyond reach.
social.author: Epicurus

social.quote: Riches rather enlarge than satisfy appetites.
social.author: Thomas Fuller

social.quote: It is an unfortunate human failing that a full pocket-book often groans more loudly than an empty stomach.
social.author: Franklin D. Roosevelt

social.quote: Increases of material comforts, it may be generally laid down, do not in any way whatsoever conduce to moral growth.
social.author: Mahatma Gandhi

social.quote: As the bee collecteth honey with great zest, so the fool collecteth wealth.
social.author: Kabir

social.quote: He who has little will receive. He who has much will be embarrassed.
social.author: Lao-tzu

social.quote: The most potent weapon in the hands of the oppressor is the mind of the oppressed.
social.author: Steve Biko

social.quote: I know not with what weapons World War III will be fought, but World War IV will be fought with sticks and stones.
social.author: Albert Einstein

social.quote: Ideas are more powerful than guns. We would not let our enemies have guns; why should we let them have ideas?
social.author: Joseph Stalin

social.quote: Profanity is the weapon of the witless.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: The human race has only one really effective weapon and that is laughter.
social.author: Mark Twain

social.quote: The interesting thing about staring down a gun barrel is how small the hole is where the bullet comes out, yet what a big difference it would make in your social schedule.
social.author: P. J. O'Rourke

social.quote: When French surrealist dramatist, Alfred Jarry, was reprimanded by a woman for firing his pistol close to her child, who might have been killed, he calmly replied, 'Madame, I would have given you another.'
social.author: Frank Stone

social.quote: Weapons are like money; no one knows the meaning of enough.
social.author: Martin Amis

social.quote: A man of courage never needs weapons, but he may need bail.
social.author: Lewis Mumford

social.quote: Books won't stay banned. They won't burn. Ideas won't go to jail. In the long run of history, the censor and the inquisitor have always lost. The only sure weapon against bad ideas is better ideas.
social.author: Alfred Whitney Griswold

social.quote: Now we are all sons of bitches.
social.author: Kenneth Bainbridge

social.quote: Far from the truth lay the antique assumption that man had fathered the weapon. The weapon, instead, had fathered man.
social.author: Robert Ardrey

social.quote: The release of atom power has changed everything except our way of thinking ... the solution to this problem lies in the heart of mankind. If only I had known, I should have become a watchmaker.
social.author: Albert Einstein

social.quote: The latest refinements of science are linked with the cruelties of the Stone Age.
social.author: Winston Churchill

social.quote: We can do without butter, but, despite all our love of peace, not without arms. One cannot shoot with butter but with guns.
social.author: Paul Joseph Goebbels

social.quote: You may be obliged to wage war, but not to use poisoned arrows.
social.author: Baltasar Gracian

social.quote: At exactly fifteen minutes past eight in the morning, on August 6, 1945, Japanese time, at the moment when the atomic bomb flashed above Hiroshima, Miss Toshiko Sasaki, a clerk in the personnel department of the East Asia Tin Works, had just sat down at her place in the plant office and was turning her head to speak to the girl at the next desk.
social.author: John Hersey

social.quote: Only technology has permitted us to put a city to the sword without quite realizing what we are doing.
social.author: Joseph Wood Krutch

social.quote: Remote control. Ingenious contradiction of terms. Fits like a handshake. Aims like a gun.
social.author: Roger Rosenblatt

social.quote: A bayonet is a weapon with a worker at both ends.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: Heaven knows we need never be ashamed of our tears, for they are rain upon the blinding dust of earth, overlying our hard hearts.
social.author: Charles Dickens

social.quote: They who are sad find somehow sweetness in tears.
social.author: Euripides

social.quote: Waste not fresh tears over old griefs.
social.author: Euripides

social.quote: Who would recognize the unhappy if grief had no language?
social.author: Publilius Syrus

social.quote: Cries of despair, misery, sobbing grief are a kind of wealth.
social.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupery

social.quote: Let tears flow of their own accord: their flowing is not inconsistent with inward peace and harmony.
social.author: Seneca

social.quote: How much better is it to weep at joy than to joy at weeping!
social.author: William Shakespeare

social.quote: To weep is to make less the depth of grief.
social.author: William Shakespeare

social.quote: Diffidence is the better part of knowledge.
social.author: Charles Caleb Colton

social.quote: Oft from new truths, and new phrase, new doubts grow, As strange attire aliens the men we know.
social.author: John Donne

social.quote: The quest for certainty blocks the search for meaning. Uncertainty is the very condition to impel man to unfold his powers.
social.author: Erich Fromm

social.quote: Doubt and mistrust are the mere panic of timid imagination, which the steadfast heart will conquer, and the large mind transcend.
social.author: Helen Keller

social.quote: It is infinitely safer to know that the man at the top has his doubts, as you and I have ours, yet has the courage to move ahead in spite of these doubts.
social.author: Rollo May

social.quote: We sail within a vast sphere, ever drifting in uncertainty, driven from end to end.
social.author: Blaise Pascal

social.quote: Atheism is rather in the lip than in the heart of man.
social.author: Francis Bacon

social.quote: There is no proselyter half so energetic as the hard-shelled atheist.
social.author: Heywood Broun

social.quote: All we have gained then by our unbelief Is a life of doubt diversified by faith, For one of faith diversified by doubt: We called the chess-board white,- we call it black.
social.author: Robert Browning

social.quote: The writers against religion, whilst they oppose every system, are wisely careful never to set up any of their own.
social.author: Edmund Burke

social.quote: To lose ones faith-surpass The loss of an Estate- Because Estates can be Replenished- faith cannot-.
social.author: Emily Dickinson

social.quote: The unbelief of the age is attested by the loud condemnation of trifles.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: If there are none [gods], All our toil is without meaning.
social.author: Euripides

social.quote: Atheism. There is not a single exalting and emancipating influence that does not in turn become inhibitory.
social.author: Andre Gide

social.quote: If there is a God, atheism must strike Him as less of an insult than religion.
social.author: Jules de Goncourt

social.quote: Daughters can spend ten per cent more than a man can make in any usual occupation.
social.author: Jubal Harshaw

social.quote: Most things get steadily worse.
social.author: Charles Issawi

social.quote: If an article is attractive, or useful, or inexpensive, they'll stop making it tomorrow; if it's all three, they stopped making it yesterday.
social.author: Mignon McLaughlin

social.quote: The length of a country's national anthem is inversely proportional to the importance of the country.
social.author: Alan L. Otten

social.quote: Things are always getting better and worse in India at the same time.
social.author: Purushottam Lai

social.quote: If there isn't a law, there will be.
social.author: Harold Faber

social.quote: The more irrevocably something is discarded, the more urgently it will be needed after it is discarded.
social.author: James Caulfeld

social.quote: A falling body always rolls to the most inaccessible place.
social.author: Theodore Bernstein

social.quote: Anything you lose automatically doubles in value.
social.author: Mignon McLaughlin

social.quote: No matter what happens there's always somebody who knew it would.
social.author: Lonny Starr

social.quote: To understand is hard. Once one understands, action is easy.
social.author: Sun Yat-sen

social.quote: You do not really understand something unless you can explain it to your grandmother.
social.author: Albert Einstein

social.quote: If you truly want to understand something, try to change it.
social.author: Kurt Lewin

social.quote: Calling George Bush shallow is like calling a dwarf short.
social.author: Molly Ivins

social.quote: It is difficult to get a man to understand something when his salary depends upon his not understanding it.
social.author: Upton Sinclair

social.quote: Anger and intolerance are the twin enemies of correct understanding.
social.author: Mahatma Gandhi

social.quote: The stupid don't even understand something that happened long ago, the wise understand it before it develops.
social.author: Shang Yang

social.quote: You never know where you're going to find the same thoughts in another brain, but when it happens you know it right off, just like you were connected by a small electrical wire that suddenly glows red hot and sparks.
social.author: Louise Erdrich

social.quote: A moment's insight is sometimes worth a life's experience.
social.author: Oliver Wendell Holmes

social.quote: Nothing can be loved or hated unless it is first known.
social.author: Leonardo da Vinci

social.quote: Ah, Love! could thou and I with Fate conspire To grasp this sorry Scheme of Things entire, Would not we shatter it to bits-and then Re-mould it nearer to the Heart's Desire!
social.author: Omar Khayyam

social.quote: Utopias rest on the fallacy that perfection is a legitimate goal of human existence.
social.author: Lewis Mumford

social.quote: Every one who has ever built anywhere a "new heaven" first found the power thereto in his own hell.
social.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

social.quote: Ideal society is a drama enacted exclusively in the imagination.
social.author: George Santayana

social.quote: A life based on reason will always require to be balanced by an occasional bout of violent and irrational emotion, for the instinctual drives must be satisfied.
social.author: Cyril Connolly

social.quote: It is our less conscious thoughts and our less conscious actions which mainly mould our lives and the lives of those who spring from us.
social.author: Samuel Butler

social.quote: How should men know what is coming to pass within them, when there are no words to grasp it? How could the drops of water know themselves to be a river? Yet the river flows on.
social.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupery

social.quote: Our unconscious is like a vast subterranean factory with intricate machinery that is never idle, where work goes on day and night from the time we are born until the moment of our death.
social.author: Milton R. Sapirstein

social.quote: There is no right to strike against the public safety by anybody, anywhere, any time.
social.author: Calvin Coolidge

social.quote: With all their faults, trade-unions have done more for humanity than any other organization of men that ever existed. They have done more for decency, for honesty for education, for the betterment of the race, for the developing of character in man, than any other association of men.
social.author: Clarence S. Darrow

social.quote: Unionism seldom, if ever, uses such power as it has to insure better work; almost always it devotes a large part of that power to safeguarding bad work.
social.author: H. L. Mencken

social.quote: In every man there is something of all men.
social.author: G. C. Lichtenberg

social.quote: Now that another is suffering pain at thy hand, trust not that thy heart shall be exempt from affliction.
social.author: Sa'di

social.quote: O! many a shaft, at random sent Finds mark the archer little meant!
social.author: Walter Scott

social.quote: Young people at universities study to achieve knowledge and not to learn a trade. We must all learn how to support ourselves, but we must also learn how to live. We need a lot of engineers in the modern world, but we do not want a world of modern engineers.
social.author: Winston Churchill

social.quote: Going to college offered me the chance to play football for four more years.
social.author: Ronald Reagan

social.quote: The only result my father got for his money was the certainty that his son had laid faultlessly the foundation of a system of heavy drinking and could be always relied upon to make a break of at least twenty-five even with a bad cue.
social.author: Flann O'Brien

social.quote: The greatest gift that Oxford gives her sons is, I truly believe, a genial irreverence toward learning, and from that irreverence love may spring.
social.author: Robertson Davies

social.quote: Colleges hate geniuses, just as convents hate saints.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: Grad school is the snooze button on the alarm clock of life.
social.author: John Rogers

social.quote: I learned three important things in college: to use a library, to memorize quickly and visually, to drop asleep any time given a horizontal surface and fifteen minutes. What I could not learn was to think creatively on schedule.
social.author: Agnes De Mille

social.quote: There was an old cannibal whose stomach suffered from so many disorders that he could only digest animals that had no spines. Thus, for years, he subsisted only upon university professors.
social.author: Louis Phillips

social.quote: You are educated. Your certification is in your degree. You may think of it as the ticket to the good life. Let me ask you to think of an alternative. Think of it as your ticket to change the world.
social.author: Tom Brokaw

social.quote: I went to the University of Life and was chucked out.
social.author: Peter Cook

social.quote: The universe is like a safe to which there is a combination-but the combination is locked up in the safe.
social.author: Peter De Vries

social.quote: The universe begins to look more like a great thought than a great machine.
social.author: Sir James Jeans

social.quote: The universe is full of magical things, patiently waiting for our wits to grow sharper.
social.author: Eden Phillpotts

social.quote: The cosmos is a gigantic fly-wheel making 10,000 revolutions a minute. Man is a sick fly taking a dizzy ride on it. Religion is the theory that the wheel was designed and set spinning to give him the ride.
social.author: H. L. Mencken

social.quote: The universe may have a purpose, but nothing we know suggests that, if so, this purpose has any similarity to ours.
social.author: Bertrand Russell

social.quote: In answer to the question of why it happened, I offer the modest proposal that our Universe is simply one of those things which happen from time to time.
social.author: Edward P. Tryon

social.quote: The usual approach of science of constructing a mathematical model cannot answer the questions of why there should be a universe for the model to describe. Why does the universe go to all the bother of existing?
social.author: Stephen Hawking

social.quote: The universe is not hostile, nor yet is it friendly. It is simply indifferent.
social.author: John Haynes Holmes

social.quote: The more comprehensible the universe becomes the more pointless it seems.
social.author: Steven Weinburg

social.quote: I don't pretend to understand the universe-it's a great deal bigger than I am ... People ought to be modester.
social.author: Thomas Carlyle

social.quote: No one is useless in this world who lightens the burden of it to anyone else.
social.author: Charles Dickens

social.quote: A scarecrow in a garden of cucumbers keepeth nothing.
social.author: Apocrypha

social.quote: A useless life is early death.
social.author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

social.quote: Uselessness is a fatal accusation to bring against any act which is done for its presumed utility, but those which are done for their own sake are their own justification.
social.author: George Santayana

social.quote: ... no man is useless while he has a friend.
social.author: Robert Louis Stevenson

social.quote: The used key is always bright.
social.author: Benjamin Franklin

social.quote: ... I never was one to get upset about a few scratches on a motor vehicle, it is meant to be used, not saved.
social.author: Garrison Keillor

social.quote: What we have never had, remains; It is the things we have that go.
social.author: Sara Teasdale

social.quote: God gives you something only you can do.
social.author: Lewis Timberlake

social.quote: There never were, since the creation of the world, two cases exactly parallel.
social.author: Lord Chesterfield

social.quote: The poetry of art is in beholding the single tower; the poetry of nature in seeing the single tree; the poetry of love in following the single woman; the poetry of religion in worshipping the single star.
social.author: G. K. Chesterton

social.quote: Every man is more than just himself; he also represents the unique, the very special and always significant and remarkable point at which the world's phenomena intersect, only once in this way and never again.
social.author: Hermann Hesse

social.quote: You have a place to fill in the world, one no one else can fill. You are important in God's plan whether you want to believe it or not.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: No one can bring to God what you can.
social.author: Steve Hawthorne

social.quote: There is nothing so easy but that it becomes difficult when you do it with reluctance.
social.author: Terence

social.quote: To reach perfection, we must all pass, one by one, through the death of self-effacement.
social.author: Dag Hammarskjold

social.quote: The small share of happiness attainable by man exists only insofar as he is able to cease to think of himself.
social.author: Theodor Reik

social.quote: In every part and corner of our life, to lose oneself is to be gainer; to forget oneself is to be happy.
social.author: Robert Louis Stevenson

social.quote: The only thing that saves the world is the little handful of disinterested men that are in it.
social.author: Woodrow Wilson

social.quote: Real unselfishness consists in sharing the interests of others.
social.author: George Santayana

social.quote: Herein lies the tragedy of the age: not that men are poor,-all men know something of poverty; not that men are wicked,-who is good? not that men are ignorant,-what is truth? Nay, but that men know so little of men.
social.author: W. E. B. Du Bois

social.quote: Each of us really understands in others only those feelings he is capable of producing himself.
social.author: Andre Gide

social.quote: It is profound philosophy to sound the depths of feeling and distinguish traits of character. Men must be studied as deeply as books.
social.author: Baltasar Gracian

social.quote: The best that can be said for anybody is probably that you misunderstood him favorably.
social.author: William Saroyan

social.quote: Many men honestly do not know what women want, and women honestly do not know why men find what they want so hard to comprehend and deliver.
social.author: Deborah Tannen

social.quote: One learns peoples through the heart, not the eyes or the intellect.
social.author: Mark Twain

social.quote: It takes longer for man to find out man than any other creature that is made.
social.author: Henry Ward Beecher

social.quote: To understand is to forgive, even oneself.
social.author: Alexander Chase

social.quote: If you do not understand a man you cannot crush him. And if you do understand him, very probably you will not.
social.author: G. K. Chesterton

social.quote: Insight-the titillating knack for hurting!
social.author: Colette

social.quote: A man willing to work, and unable to find work, is perhaps the saddest sight that fortune's inequality exhibits under this sun.
social.author: Thomas Carlyle

social.quote: It were depression, too. They cut my wages down once at the foundry. They cut my wages down again. Then they cut my wages out, also the job.
social.author: Langston Hughes

social.quote: Anyone who has ever experienced dehumanized life on welfare or any other confidence-shaking dependency knows that a paid job may be preferable to the dole, even when the handout is coming from a family member.
social.author: Gloria Steinem

social.quote: I have known some men possessed of good qualities which were very serviceable to others, but useless to themselves; like a sun-dial on the front of a house, to inform the neighbours and passengers, but not the owner within.
social.author: Jonathan Swift

social.quote: We often despise what is most useful to us.
social.author: Aesop

social.quote: It is a great misfortune to be of use to nobody; scarcely less to be of use to everybody.
social.author: Baltasar Gracian

social.quote: A man cannot sleep in his cradle: whatever is useful must in the nature of life become useless.
social.author: Walter Lippmann

social.quote: Success can corrupt; usefulness can only exalt.
social.author: Dmitri Mitropoulos

social.quote: Utility is the great idol of the age, to which all powers must do service and all talents swear allegiance.
social.author: Friedrich von Schiller

social.quote: The difference between utility and utility plus beauty is the difference between telephone wires and the spiders web.
social.author: Edwin Way Teale

social.quote: The sure way of knowing nothing about life is to try to make oneself useful.
social.author: Oscar Wilde

social.quote: Our insignificance is often the cause of our safety.
social.author: Aesop

social.quote: Rightly viewed no meanest object is insignificant; all objects are as windows, through which the philosophic eye looks into infinitude itself.
social.author: Thomas Carlyle

social.quote: A man can look upon his life and accept it as good or evil; it is far, far harder for him to confess that it has been unimportant in the sum of things.
social.author: Murray Kempton

social.quote: Strange how few, After alls said and done, the things that are Of moment.
social.author: Edna St. Vincent Millay

social.quote: The fairest thing we can experience is the mysterious. It is the fundamental emotion which stands at the cradle of true art and true science.
social.author: Albert Einstein

social.quote: All is riddle, and the key to a riddle is another riddle.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: Between the idea And the reality Between the motion And the act Falls the Shadow.
social.author: T. S. Eliot

social.quote: Grieve not, because thou understandest not life's mystery; behind the veil is concealed many a delight.
social.author: Hafiz

social.quote: The difference between what the most and the least learned people know is inexpressibly trivial in relation to that which is unknown.
social.author: Albert Einstein

social.quote: Tis very puzzling on the brink Of what is called Eternity to stare, And know no more of what is here, than there.
social.author: Lord Byron

social.quote: Penetrating so many secrets, we cease to believe in the unknowable. But there it sits nevertheless, calmly licking its chops.
social.author: H. L. Mencken

social.quote: Would there be this eternal seeking if the found existed?
social.author: Antonio Porchia

social.quote: Our dream dashes itself against the great mystery like a wasp against a window pane. Less merciful than man, God never opens the window.
social.author: Jules Renard

social.quote: We are ignorant of the Beyond because this ignorance is the condition sine qua non of our own life. Just as ice cannot know fire except by melting, by vanishing.
social.author: Jules Renard

social.quote: It's better to be unhappy alone than unhappy with someone.
social.author: Marilyn Monroe

social.quote: I don't want to be alone, I want to be left alone.
social.author: Audrey Hepburn

social.quote: Your heart just breaks, that's all. But you can't judge or point fingers. You just have to be lucky enough to find someone who appreciates you.
social.author: Audrey Hepburn

social.quote: A man should always consider how much he has more than he wants, and how much more unhappy he might be than he really is.
social.author: Joseph Addison

social.quote: Nothing is miserable unless you think it so.
social.author: Boethius

social.quote: Melancholy cannot be clearly proved to others, so it is better to be silent about it.
social.author: James Boswell

social.quote: Naught so sweet as melancholy.
social.author: Robert Burton

social.quote: There are no grounds for supposing that one can live a life without pain and sadness, but is it wrong to believe that somehow, somewhere, this is possible?
social.author: Hubert Butler

social.quote: For the unhappy man death is the commutation of a sentence of life imprisonment.
social.author: Alexander Chase

social.quote: The Morning after Woe- Tis frequently the Way- Surpasses all that rose before- For utter Jubilee-.
social.author: Emily Dickinson

social.quote: Unity cannot be taken for granted.
social.author: Jomo Kenyatta

social.quote: Unity and victory are synonymous.
social.author: Samora Machel

social.quote: The civilization of the twentieth century cannot be universal except by being a dynamic synthesis of all the cultural values of all civilizations. It will be monstrous unless it is seasoned with the salt of negri-tude, for it will be without the savor of humanity.
social.author: Leopold Sedar Senghor

social.quote: I believe in the essential unity of man, and for that matter, of all lives. Therefore, I believe that if one man gains spiritually, the whole world gains with him, and if one man falls, the whole world falls to that extent.
social.author: Mahatma Gandhi

social.quote: All for one, and one for all.
social.author: Alexandre Dumas

social.quote: All your strength is in your union, All your danger is in discord; Therefore be at peace henceforward, And as brothers live together.
social.author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

social.quote: Union gives strength to the humble.
social.author: Publilius Syrus

social.quote: A common danger unites even the bitterest enemies.
social.author: Aristotle

social.quote: We must all hang together, or assuredly we shall all hang separately.
social.author: Benjamin Franklin

social.quote: The United Nations was set up not to get us to heaven, but only to save us from hell.
social.author: Winston Churchill

social.quote: Our instrument and our hope is the United Nations, and I see little merit in the impatience of those who would abandon this imperfect world instrument because they dislike our imperfect world.
social.author: John F. Kennedy

social.quote: ... The real victim is the future.
social.author: Dag Hammarskjold

social.quote: Let us make this floor the last battlefield.
social.author: Gen. Carlos P. Romulo

social.quote: The voice is a second face.
social.author: Gerard Bauer

social.quote: Like music on the waters is thy sweet voice to me.
social.author: Lord Byron

social.quote: Her voice was ever soft, Gentle, and low, an excellent thing in woman.
social.author: William Shakespeare

social.quote: Vitality shows in not only the ability to persist but the ability to start over.
social.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald

social.quote: The difference between the university graduate and the autodidact lies not so much in the extent of knowledge as in the extent of vitality and self-confidence.
social.author: Milan Kundera

social.quote: When vitality runs high, death takes men by surprise. But if they close their eyes to this possibility, what they gain in peace they lose in sensibility and significance.
social.author: Lewis Mumford

social.quote: Human vitality is so exuberant that in the sorriest desert it still finds a pretext for glowing and trembling.
social.author: Jose Ortega y Gasset

social.quote: Nature drives with a loose rein and vitality of any sort can blunder through many a predicament in which reason would despair.
social.author: George Santayana

social.quote: That there should absolutely be nothing at all is utterly impossible. The mind, let it stretch its conceptions ever so far, can never so much as bring itself to conceive of a state of perfect nothing.
social.author: Jonathan Edwards

social.quote: The vow that binds too strictly snaps itself.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: If one man offers you democracy and another offers you a bag of grain, at what stage of starvation will you prefer the grain to the vote?
social.author: Bertrand Russell

social.quote: Voting is a civic sacrament.
social.author: Theodore Hesburgh

social.quote: Bad officials are elected by good citizens who do not vote.
social.author: George Jean Nathan

social.quote: Elections are won by men and women chiefly because most people vote against somebody, rather than for somebody.
social.author: Franklin P. Adams

social.quote: To make democracy work, we must be a nation of participants, not simply observers. One who does not vote has no right to complain.
social.author: Louis L'Amour

social.quote: Voting is simply a way of determining which side is the stronger without putting it to the test of fighting.
social.author: H. L. Mencken

social.quote: Vote for the man who promises least; he'll be the least disappointing.
social.author: Bernard Baruch

social.quote: A man without a vote is in this land like a man without a hand.
social.author: Henry Ward Beecher

social.quote: At the bottom of all the tributes paid to democracy is the little man, walking into the little booth, with a little pencil, making a little cross on a little bit of paper-no amount of rhetoric or voluminous discussion can possibly diminish the overwhelming importance of the point.
social.author: Winston Churchill

social.quote: Disfranchisement is the deliberate theft and robbery of the only protection of poor against rich and black against white.
social.author: W. E. B. Du Bois

social.quote: Those who stay away from the election think that one vote will do no good: Tis but one step more to think one vote will do no harm.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: The apathy of the modern voter is the confusion of the modern reformer.
social.author: Learned Hand

social.quote: The vote is the most powerful instrument ever devised by man for breaking down injustice and destroying the terrible walls which imprison men because they are different from other men.
social.author: Lyndon B. Johnson

social.quote: Everyone is, in his own way, vulnerable.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: To be is to be vulnerable.
social.author: Norman O. Brown

social.quote: Violence never settles anything right: apart from injuring your own soul, it injures the best cause. It lingers on long after the object of hate has disappeared from the scene to plague the lives of those who have employed it against their foes.
social.author: Obafemi Awolowo

social.quote: ... I am an uncompromising opponent of violent methods even to serve the noblest of causes ...
social.author: Mahatma Gandhi

social.quote: The power which establishes a state is violence; the power which maintains it is violence; the power which eventually overthrows it is violence.
social.author: Kenneth Kaunda

social.quote: Wherever a people has grown savage in arms so that human laws have no longer any place among it, the only powerful means of reducing it is religion.
social.author: Giambattista Vico

social.quote: Poverty is the worst form of violence.
social.author: Mahatma Gandhi

social.quote: God, in His wisdom, has so linked the whole human family together that any violence done at one end of the chain is felt throughout its length.
social.author: Elizabeth Cady Stanton

social.quote: Now at last the slowly gathered, long-pent-up fury of the storm broke upon us. Four or five millions of men met each other in the first shock of the most merciless of all the wars of which record has been kept.
social.author: Winston Churchill

social.quote: Violence is just where kindness is vain.
social.author: Pierre Corneille

social.quote: God hates violence. He has ordained that all men fairly possess their property, not seize it.
social.author: Euripides

social.quote: Not only do most people accept violence if it is perpetuated by legitimate authority, they also regard violence against certain kinds of people as inherently legitimate, no matter who commits it.
social.author: Edgar Z. Friedenberg

social.quote: ... one may smile, and smile, and be a villain.
social.author: William Shakespeare

social.quote: Vigor is contagious; and whatever makes us either think or feel strongly adds to our power and enlarges our field of action.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: Nowhere does the Bible say that anyone was seeking a vision when it came. They just happened without their seeking it.
social.author: Kenneth Haigh

social.quote: Nothing will benefit human health and increase the chances for survival of life on earth as much as the evolution to a vegetarian diet.
social.author: Albert Einstein

social.quote: I am not a complete vegetarian. I eat only animals that have died in their sleep.
social.author: George Carlin

social.quote: Are there any vegetarians among cannibals?
social.author: Stanislaw J. Lec

social.quote: Why we ourselves are the living graves of murdered beasts, how can we expect any ideal conditions on this earth?
social.author: George Bernard Shaw

social.quote: Vegetarian: a person who eats only side dishes.
social.author: Gerald Lieberman

social.quote: I don't myself believe that ... we have the right to kill animals. I know I would not have the right to kill you, however painlessly, just because I liked your flavour, and I am not in a position to judge that your life is worth more to you than the animal's to it.
social.author: Brigid Brophy

social.quote: You have just dined, and however scrupulously the slaughterhouse is concealed in the graceful distance of miles, there is complicity.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: The sweet life has always attracted travelers, to Venice in the months of the famous Carnival and elsewhere at different times of the year, down the centuries.
social.author: Luigi Barzini

social.quote: Venice is like eating an entire box of chocolate liqueurs in one go.
social.author: Truman Capote

social.quote: The perennial wonder of Venice is to peer at herself in her canals and find that she exists-incredible as it seems. It is the same reassurance that a looking-glass offers us: the guarantee that we are real.
social.author: Mary McCarthy

social.quote: The rationalist mind has always had its doubts about Venice. The watery city receives a dry inspection, as though it were a myth for the credulous- poets and honeymooners.
social.author: Mary McCarthy

social.quote: This grossly advertised wonder [Venice], this gold idol with clay feet, this trompe-l'oeil, this painted deception, this cliche-what intelligent iconoclast could fail to experience a destructive impulse in her presence?
social.author: Mary McCarthy

social.quote: Venice is the worlds unconscious: a misers glittering hoard, guarded by a Beast whose eyes are made of white agate, and by a saint who is really a prince who has just slain a dragon.
social.author: Mary McCarthy

social.quote: Is there anyone but must repress a secret thrill, on arriving in Venice for the first time-or returning thither after long absence-and stepping into a Venetian gondola?
social.author: Thomas Mann

social.quote: Looking, he thought that to come to Venice by the station is like entering a palace by the back door.
social.author: Thomas Mann

social.quote: Variety's the very spice of life, That gives it all its flavor.
social.author: William Cowper

social.quote: It is the function of vice to keep virtue within reasonable bounds.
social.author: Samuel Butler

social.quote: Crime and vice generally require darkness for prowling. They disappear when light plays upon them.
social.author: Mahatma Gandhi

social.quote: Vices are their own punishment.
social.author: Aesop

social.quote: We are more apt to catch the vices of others than their virtues, as disease is far more contagious than health.
social.author: Charles Caleb Colton

social.quote: The gods are just, and of our pleasant vices Make instruments to scourge us.
social.author: William Shakespeare

social.quote: The most malignant of enemies is the lust which abides within.
social.author: Sadi of Shiraz

social.quote: We make a ladder of our vices, if we trample those same vices underfoot.
social.author: St. Augustine

social.quote: Half the vices which the world condemns most loudly have seeds of good in them and require moderate use rather than total abstinence.
social.author: Samuel Butler

social.quote: Let them show me a cottage where there are not the same vices of which they accuse courts.
social.author: Lord Chesterfield

social.quote: When all run by common consent into vice, none appear to do so.
social.author: Charles Caleb Colton

social.quote: To be a complete victim may be another source of power.
social.author: Iris Murdoch

social.quote: Lust is the craving for salt of a man who is dying of thirst.
social.author: Frederick Buechner

social.quote: You bet I did. And I enjoyed it.
social.author: Michael Bloomberg

social.quote: Vice is its own reward.
social.author: Quentin Crisp

social.quote: Vice is nice, but liquor is quicker.
social.author: Dorothy Parker

social.quote: Virtue consists in avoiding scandal and venereal disease.
social.author: Robert Cecil

social.quote: Virtue is praised but hated. People run away from it, for it is ice cold and in this world you must keep your feet warm.
social.author: Denis Diderot

social.quote: A vice is merely a pleasure to which somebody has objected.
social.author: Robin Skelton

social.quote: Virtue has its own reward but no sale at the box office.
social.author: Mae West

social.quote: Often devotion to virtue arises from sated desire.
social.author: Laurence Hope

social.quote: All the Christian virtues rolled into one make a ball that won't bounce.
social.author: Nigel Nicolson

social.quote: The artisan or scientist or the follower of whatever discipline who has the habit of comparing himself not with other followers but with the discipline itself will have a lower opinion of himself, the more excellent he is.
social.author: Giacomo Leopardi

social.quote: The price one pays for pursuing any profession, or calling, is an intimate knowledge of its ugly side.
social.author: James Baldwin

social.quote: Vocations which we wanted to pursue, but didn't, bleed, like colors, on the whole of our existence.
social.author: Honore de Balzac

social.quote: The professionals resemble and recognize each other by virtue of the stigmata that their trade has left upon them. They are like the dog in the fable, whose collar has made an indelible mark around his neck. The amateur is the shaggy wolf whom no dog had better trust too far.
social.author: Jacques Barzun

social.quote: Blessed is he who has found his work; let him ask no other blessedness.
social.author: Thomas Carlyle

social.quote: Every man has his own vocation. The talent is the call.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: The player envies only the player, the poet envies only the poet.
social.author: William Hazlitt

social.quote: Every calling is great when greatly pursued.
social.author: Oliver Wendell Holmes

social.quote: Every science has for its basis a system of principles as fixed and unalterable as those by which the universe is regulated and governed. Man cannot make principles; he can only discover them.
social.author: Thomas Paine

social.quote: When men are rightly occupied, their amusement grows out of their work, as the colour-petals out of a fruitful flower.
social.author: John Ruskin

social.quote: Avoid dishonest gain; no price can recompense the pang of vice.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: If we tread our vices under our feet, we make of them a ladder by which to rise to higher things.
social.author: St. Augustine

social.quote: This is the essential evil of vice: it debases a man.
social.author: Edwin Hubbel Chapin

social.quote: Search others for their virtues, thyself for thy vices.
social.author: Benjamin Franklin

social.quote: As virtue is its own reward, so vice is its own punishment.
social.author: Thomas Fuller

social.quote: When our vices leave us, we flatter ourselves with the credit of having left them.
social.author: Francois de La Rochefoucauld

social.quote: Spare the person but lash the vice.
social.author: Martial

social.quote: He that can apprehend and consider vice with all her baits and seeming pleasures, and yet abstain, and yet distinguish and prefer that which is truly better, he is the true warfaring Christian.
social.author: John Milton

social.quote: A desire to be observed, considered, esteemed, praised, beloved, and admired by his fellows is one of the earliest as well as the keenest dispositions discovered in the heart of man.
social.author: John Adams

social.quote: He wanted to be the bride at every wedding and the corpse at every funeral.
social.author: Alice Roosevelt Longworth

social.quote: I'll destroy you. I am the master of disaster.
social.author: Muhammad Ali

social.quote: In my opinion, better far it be To destroy vanity within my life Than to destroy my life in vanity.
social.author: Juana Ines de la Cruz

social.quote: Fools take to themselves the respect that is given to their office.
social.author: Aesop

social.quote: There is no such flatterer as is a man's self.
social.author: Francis Bacon

social.quote: None of us are so much praised or censured as we think.
social.author: Charles Caleb Colton

social.quote: The anxiety we have for the figure we cut, for our personage, is constantly cropping out. We are showing off and are often more concerned with making a display than with living. Whoever feels observed observes himself.
social.author: Andre Gide

social.quote: Until the Donkey tried to clear The Fence, he thought himself a Deer.
social.author: Arthur Guiterman

social.quote: Without vanity a writer's work is tepid, and he must accept his vanity as part of his stock in trade and live with it as one of the hazards of his profession.
social.author: Moss Hart

social.quote: Try not to be a person of success, but rather a person of virtue.
social.author: Albert Einstein

social.quote: The highest virtue is always against the law.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: Wisdom is knowing what to do next; virtue is doing it.
social.author: David Starr Jordan

social.quote: All sober inquirers after truth, ancient and modern, pagan and Christian, have declared that the happiness of man, as well as his dignity, consists in virtue.
social.author: John Adams

social.quote: Public virtue cannot exist in a nation without private, and public virtue is the only foundation of republics.
social.author: John Adams

social.quote: A state of temperance, sobriety and justice without devotion is a cold, lifeless, insipid condition of virtue, and is rather to be styled philosophy than religion.
social.author: Joseph Addison

social.quote: Virtue is more clearly shown in the performance of fine actions than in the nonperformance of base ones.
social.author: Aristotle

social.quote: Virtue is like precious odours,-most fragrant when they are incensed or crushed.
social.author: Francis Bacon

social.quote: A virtue to be serviceable must, like gold, be alloyed with some commoner but more durable metal.
social.author: Samuel Butler

social.quote: Abstract qualities begin With capitals alway: The True, the Good, the Beautiful- Those are the things that pay!
social.author: Lewis Carroll

social.quote: Those who are addicted to the phrase "to use a vulgarism" expect to achieve the feat of being at once vulgar and superior to vulgarity.
social.author: H. W. Fowler

social.quote: The vulgar man is always the most distinguished, for the very desire to be distinguished is vulgar.
social.author: G. K. Chesterton

social.quote: It is disgusting to pick your teeth; what is vulgar is to use a gold toothpick.
social.author: Louis Kronenbergerer

social.quote: I have the simplest tastes. I am always satisfied with the best.
social.author: Oscar Wilde

social.quote: Bad taste creates many more millionaires than good taste.
social.author: Charles Bukowski

social.quote: She's a very charming and delightful creature ... and has only one fault that I know of. It happens, unfortunately, that that single blemish is a want of taste. She don't like me.
social.author: Charles Dickens

social.quote: The essence of taste is suitability. Divest the word of its prim and priggish implications, and see how it expresses the mysterious demand of the eye and mind for symmetry, harmony and order.
social.author: Edith Wharton

social.quote: It is only with great vulgarity that you can achieve real refinement, only out of bawdy that you can get tenderness.
social.author: Lawrence Durrell

social.quote: What is exhilarating in bad taste is the aristocratic pleasure of giving offence.
social.author: Charles Baudelaire

social.quote: Nothing is more vulgar than haste.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: I have always eaten animal flesh with a somewhat guilty conscience.
social.author: Albert Einstein

social.quote: Respect animals; don't eat them.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: Most vigitaryans I iver see looked enough like their food to be classed as cannybals.
social.author: Finley Peter Dunne

social.quote: I have no doubt that it is a part of the destiny of the human race, in its gradual improvement, to leave off eating animals, as surely as the savage tribes have left off eating each other when they came in contact with the more civilized.
social.author: Henry David Thoreau

social.quote: Meat is murder.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: A vegetarian is a person who won't eat anything that can have children.
social.author: David Brenner

social.quote: Show me a community or a country where all the minor vices are discouraged and I will show you one bereft of major virtues.
social.author: Heywood Broun

social.quote: If virtue cannot shine bright, but by the conflict of contrary appetites, shall we then say that she cannot subsist without the assistance of vice, and that it is from her that she derives her reputation and honor?
social.author: Michel de Montaigne

social.quote: They that endeavour to abolish vice, destroy also virtue; for contraries, though they destroy one another, are yet the life of one another.
social.author: Thomas Browne

social.quote: Vice has more martyrs than virtue; and it often happens that men suffer more to be lost than to be saved.
social.author: Charles Caleb Colton

social.quote: This is the tax a man must pay to his virtues-they hold up a torch to his vices, and render those frailties notorious in him which would have passed without observation in another.
social.author: Charles Caleb Colton

social.quote: Men imagine that they communicate their virtue or vice only by overt actions, and do not see that virtue or vice emit a breath every moment.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: There is a capacity of virtue in us, and there is a capacity of vice to make your blood creep.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: Search others for their virtues, thy self for thy vices.
social.author: Benjamin Franklin

social.quote: Our virtues are most frequently but vices disguised.
social.author: Francois de La Rochefoucauld

social.quote: Vices are ingredients of virtues just as poisons are ingredients of remedies. Prudence mixes and tempers them and uses them effectively against life's ills.
social.author: Francois de La Rochefoucauld

social.quote: One of the most wonderful things in nature is a glance of the eye; it transcends speech; it is the bodily symbol of identity.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: True vision is always twofold. It involves emotional comprehension as well as physical perception. Yet how rarely we have either. We generally only glance at an object long enough to tag it with a name.
social.author: Ross Parmenter

social.quote: No man sees far; the most see no farther than their noses.
social.author: Thomas Carlyle

social.quote: Visionary people are visionary partly because of the very great many things they don't see.
social.author: Berkeley Rice

social.quote: Hundreds of people can talk for one who can think, but thousands can think for one who can see. To see clearly is poetry, prophecy, and religion-all in one.
social.author: John Ruskin

social.quote: A rock pile ceases to be a rock pile the moment a single man contemplates it, bearing within him the image of a cathedral.
social.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupery

social.quote: Vision is the art of seeing things invisible.
social.author: Jonathan Swift

social.quote: Remembering and seeing are not the same, and that is why memories are of little use to us in forming loving relationships.
social.author: Gerald Jampolsky

social.quote: Nobody sees anybody truly but only through the flaws of their own ego.
social.author: Tennessee Williams

social.quote: Better one-eyed than stone-blind.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: Virginity is not honored simply because it is virginity, but because it is consecrated of God.
social.author: Augustine of Hippo

social.quote: Whenever you are confronted with an opponent. Conquer him with love.
social.author: Mahatma Gandhi

social.quote: Victory breeds hatred, for the conquered is unhappy. The calm one is he who has given up both victory and defeat.
social.author: Dhammapada

social.quote: Although our fight will be long and hard, our people are resolved to fight till final victory.
social.author: Ho Chi Minh

social.quote: The first step on the way to victory is to recognize the enemy.
social.author: Corrie ten Boom

social.quote: A nation which makes the final sacrifice for life and freedom does not get beaten.
social.author: Mustafa Kemal Ataturk

social.quote: We do not rejoice in victories. We rejoice when a new kind of cotton is grown and when strawberries bloom in Israel.
social.author: Golda Meir

social.quote: The victor belongs to the spoils.
social.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald

social.quote: There is no pain in the wound received in the moment of victory.
social.author: Publilius Syrus

social.quote: Nothing is intrinsically valuable; the value of everything is attributed to it, assigned to it from outside the thing itself, by people.
social.author: John Barth

social.quote: Life's values originate in circumstances over which the individual has no control.
social.author: Charles A. Lindbergh

social.quote: The hierarchy of power is not the same as the hierarchy of value. A good human is higher than the animals on both scales; an evil human is high on the scale of power, but at the very bottom of the scale of values.
social.author: Wendell Berry

social.quote: Authentic values are those by which a life can be lived, which can form a people that produces great deeds and thoughts.
social.author: Allan Bloom

social.quote: The world is an old woman, and mistakes any gilt farthing for a gold coin; whereby being often cheated, she will thenceforth trust nothing but the common copper.
social.author: Thomas Carlyle

social.quote: That which cost little is less valued.
social.author: Miguel de Cervantes

social.quote: Let him go where he will, he can only find so much beauty or worth as he carries.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: The world is always curious, and people become valuable merely for their inaccessibility
social.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald

social.quote: What we must decide is perhaps how we are valuable rather than how valuable we are.
social.author: Edgar Z. Friedenberg

social.quote: Having lost religious faith and the humanistic values bound up with it, he [man] concentrated on technical and material values and lost the capacity for deep emotional experiences, for the joy and sadness that accompany them.
social.author: Erich Fromm

social.quote: Few men are wantonly wicked.
social.author: Mahatma Gandhi

social.quote: One may detest the wickedness of a brother without hating him.
social.author: Mahatma Gandhi

social.quote: Do good even to the wicked; it is as well to shut a dog's mouth with a crumb.
social.author: Saadi

social.quote: As for an authentic villain, the real thing, the absolute, the artist, one rarely meets him even once in a lifetime. The ordinary bad hat is always in part a decent fellow.
social.author: Colette

social.quote: A belief in a supernatural source of evil is not necessary; men alone are quite capable of every wickedness.
social.author: Joseph Conrad

social.quote: Wicked is not much worse than indiscreet.
social.author: John Donne

social.quote: It is an esoteric doctrine of society, that a little wickedness is good to make muscle; as if conscience were not good for hands and legs.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: The unrighteous are never really fortunate.
social.author: Euripides

social.quote: Wickedness is always easier than virtue, for it takes the short cut to everything.
social.author: Samuel Johnson

social.quote: There are many humorous things in the world, among them the white man's notion that he is less savage than the other savages.
social.author: Mark Twain

social.quote: This world is white no longer, and it will never be white again.
social.author: James Baldwin

social.quote: There can be no whiter whiteness than this one: An insurance man's shirt on its morning run.
social.author: Gwendolyn Brooks

social.quote: If we develop the force of will, we shall find that we do not need the force of arms.
social.author: Mahatma Gandhi

social.quote: Strength does not come from physical capacity. It comes from an indomitable will.
social.author: Mahatma Gandhi

social.quote: What is the highest secret of victory and peace? To will what God wills, and strike a league with destiny.
social.author: William R. Alger

social.quote: The will is never free-it is always attached to an object, a purpose. It is simply the engine in the car- it can't steer.
social.author: Joyce Cary

social.quote: Will cannot be quenched against its will.
social.author: Dante Alighieri

social.quote: Will and Wisdom are both mighty leaders. Our times worship Will.
social.author: Clarence Day

social.quote: The good or ill of man lies within his own will.
social.author: Epictetus

social.quote: A fat kitchen, a lean will.
social.author: Benjamin Franklin

social.quote: I wish it, I command it. Let my will take the place of a reason.
social.author: Juvenal

social.quote: Man's will creates the things that paralyze his brain and brutalize his heart.
social.author: Max Lerner

social.quote: I have too many fantasies to be a housewife... I guess I am a fantasy.
social.author: Marilyn Monroe

social.quote: A man's wife has more power over him than the state has.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: Man's best possession is a sympathetic wife.
social.author: Euripides

social.quote: Choose a wife rather by your ear than your eye.
social.author: Thomas Fuller

social.quote: My wife has a black belt in body language.
social.author: Daren King

social.quote: I would be married, but I'd have no wife, I would be married to a single life.
social.author: Richard Crashaw

social.quote: The man who thinks his wife, his baby, his house, his horse, his dog, and himself severally unequalled, is almost sure to be a good-humored person, though liable to be tedious at times.
social.author: Oliver Wendell Holmes

social.quote: He that hath wife and children hath given hostages to fortune; for they are impediments to great enterprises, either of virtue or mischief.
social.author: Francis Bacon

social.quote: When cheated, wife or husband feels the same.
social.author: Euripides

social.quote: A wife loves out of duty, and duty leads to constraint, and constraint kills desire.
social.author: Jean Giraudoux

social.quote: When a man's Willing and eager, god joins in.
social.author: Aeschylus

social.quote: A willing mind makes a light foot.
social.author: Thomas Fuller

social.quote: Nothing is impossible to a willing heart.
social.author: John Heywood

social.quote: Nothing is troublesome that we do willingly.
social.author: Thomas Jefferson

social.quote: If you agree to carry a calf, they'll make you carry the cow.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: A good horse should be seldom spurred.
social.author: Thomas Fuller

social.quote: All lay load on the willing horse.
social.author: Thomas Fuller

social.quote: The one who pulls is the one they urge on.
social.author: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn

social.quote: Never grow a wishbone where your backbone ought to be.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: Mine is a most peaceable disposition. My wishes are a humble cottage with a thatched roof, but a good bed, good food, the freshest milk and butter, flowers before my window, and a few fine trees before my door; and if God wants to make my happiness complete, He will grant me the joy of seeing some six or seven of my enemies hanging from those trees.
social.author: Heinrich Heine

social.quote: Few people know so clearly what they want. Most people can't even think what to hope for when they throw a penny in the fountain.
social.author: Barbara Kingsolver

social.quote: A wise girl kisses but doesn't love, listens but doesn't believe, and leaves before she is left.
social.author: Marilyn Monroe

social.quote: It is better to remain silent and be thought a fool than to open one's mouth and remove all doubt.
social.author: Abraham Lincoln

social.quote: Whenever you find yourself on the side of the majority, it is time to pause and reflect.
social.author: Mark Twain

social.quote: Knowing yourself is the beginning of all wisdom.
social.author: Aristotle

social.quote: Never, never, never give in!
social.author: Winston Churchill

social.quote: No man is poor who has a Godly mother.
social.author: Abraham Lincoln

social.quote: The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.
social.author: Socrates

social.quote: Honesty is the first chapter of the book wisdom.
social.author: Thomas Jefferson

social.quote: The saddest aspect of life right now is that science gathers knowledge faster than society gathers wisdom.
social.author: Isaac Asimov

social.quote: The older I grow, the more I distrust the familiar doctrine that age brings wisdom.
social.author: H. L. Mencken

social.quote: Every mile is two in winter.
social.author: George Herbert

social.quote: I like winter because I can stay indoors without feeling guilty.
social.author: Teressa Skelton

social.quote: I read, much of the night, and go south in the winter.
social.author: T. S. Eliot

social.quote: Winter is not a season, it's an occupation.
social.author: Sinclair Lewis

social.quote: God is day and night, winter and summer, war and peace, satiety and want.
social.author: Heraclitus

social.quote: Blow, blow, thou winter wind, Thou are not so unkind As man's ingratitude.
social.author: William Shakespeare

social.quote: If Winter comes, can Spring be far behind?
social.author: Percy Bysshe Shelley

social.quote: Let us love winter, for it is the spring of genius.
social.author: Pietro Aretino

social.quote: No Winter lasts forever, no Spring skips its turn. April is a promise that May is bound to keep, and we know it.
social.author: Hal Borland

social.quote: Honest winter, snow-clad and with the frosted beard, I can welcome not uncordially; but that long deferment of the calendar s promise, that weeping gloom of March and April, that bitter blast outraging the honour of May-how often has it robbed me of heart and hope.
social.author: George Gissing

social.quote: When one door of happiness closes, another opens; but often we look so long at the closed door that we do not see the one which has been opened for us.
social.author: Helen Keller

social.quote: Before God we are all equally wise-equally foolish.
social.author: Albert Einstein

social.quote: It is better to be alone than in bad company.
social.author: George Washington

social.quote: Don't gain the world and lose your soul, wisdom is better than silver or gold.
social.author: Bob Marley

social.quote: Things don't change. You change your way of looking, that's all.
social.author: Carlos Castaneda

social.quote: A man should never be ashamed to own that he has been in the wrong, which is but saying, in other words, that he is wiser today than he was yesterday.
social.author: Jonathan Swift

social.quote: Friendship of the wise is good; a wise enemy is better than a foolish friend.
social.author: Rumi

social.quote: Just as solid rocks are not shaken by the wind, so wise men are not moved by either blame or praise.
social.author: Dhammapada

social.quote: Great wisdom is generous; petty wisdom is contentious.
social.author: Chuang-tzu

social.quote: Cynicism is a sorry kind of wisdom.
social.author: Barack Obama

social.quote: Who has seen the wind? Neither you nor I: But when the trees bow down their heads The wind is passing by.
social.author: Christina Rossetti

social.quote: The East Wind, an interloper in the dominions of Westerly Weather, is an impassive-faced tyrant with a sharp poniard held behind his back for a treacherous stab.
social.author: Joseph Conrad

social.quote: The Westerly Wind asserting his sway from the south-west quarter is often like a monarch gone mad, driving forth with wild imprecations the most faithful of his courtiers to shipwreck, disaster, and death.
social.author: Joseph Conrad

social.quote: The substance of the winds is too thin for human eyes, their written language is too difficult for human minds, and their spoken language mostly too faint for the ears.
social.author: John Muir

social.quote: O wild West Wind, thou breath of Autumns being, Thou, from whose unseen presence the leaves dead Are driven, like ghosts from an enchanter fleeing, Yellow, and black, and pale, and hectic red, Pestilence-stricken multitudes.
social.author: Percy Bysshe Shelley

social.quote: O wind, a-blowing all day long, O wind, that sings so loud a song!
social.author: Robert Louis Stevenson

social.quote: I cannot explain the wind, but I can hoist a sail.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: Witnessing is one beggar telling another beggar where to find food.
social.author: Lewis Timberlake

social.quote: People can see when you've got good news.
social.author: Grenville Barber

social.quote: The way from God to a human heart is through a human heart.
social.author: S. D. Gordon

social.quote: Witnessing is not a spare-time occupation or a once-a-week activity. It must be a quality of life. You don't go witnessing, you are a witness.
social.author: Dan Greene

social.quote: What we have to share that's most powerful is what God has done for us.
social.author: Ron Parrish

social.quote: Where you stand depends on where you sit.
social.author: Nelson Mandela

social.quote: Ask me no questions, and I'll tell you no lies.
social.author: Oliver Goldsmith

social.quote: The covers of this book are too far apart.
social.author: Ambrose Bierce

social.quote: The world was my oyster but I used the wrong fork.
social.author: Oscar Wilde

social.quote: The small amount of foolery wise men have makes a great show.
social.author: William Shakespeare

social.quote: I am not absentminded. It is the presence of mind that makes me unaware of everything else.
social.author: G. K. Chesterton

social.quote: If you ask me anything I don't know, I'm not going to answer.
social.author: Yogi Berra
