social.quote: One must have a heart of stone to read the death of little Nell without laughing.
social.author: Oscar Wilde

social.quote: Every habit makes our hand more witty, and out wit more handy.
social.author: Friedrich Nietzsche

social.quote: He who does not hope to win has already lost.
social.author: Jose Joaquin Olmedo

social.quote: You have deeply ventured; But all must do so who would greatly win.
social.author: Lord Byron

social.quote: Fields are won by those who believe in winning.
social.author: Thomas Wentworth Higginson

social.quote: Winning is overemphasized. The only time it is really important is in surgery and war.
social.author: Al McGuire

social.quote: When you win, nothing hurts.
social.author: Joe Namath

social.quote: Win as if you were used to it, lose as if you enjoyed it for a change.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: There's nothing to winning, really. That is, if you happen to be blessed with a keen eye, and agile mind, and no scruples whatsoever.
social.author: Alfred Hitchcock

social.quote: If you can play as if it means nothing when it means everything, then you are hard to beat.
social.author: Steve Davis

social.quote: Losses are always a relief. They take a great burden off me, make me feel more normal. If I win several tournaments in a row I get so confident I'm in a cloud. A loss gets me eager again.
social.author: Chris Evert

social.quote: Finish last in your league and they call you idiot. Finish last in medical school and they call you doctor.
social.author: Abe Lemons

social.quote: Winning is overrated. The only time it is really important is in surgery and war.
social.author: Al McGuire

social.quote: Supporting the English cricket team is like supporting a second division football team. I support Norwich City football team and when they lose I really don't mind because I expect them to; but when we win I'm so happy - much happier than any Arsenal supporter could ever be.
social.author: Stephen Fry

social.quote: We would often be sorry if our wishes were gratified.
social.author: Aesop

social.quote: If wishes were fishes, beggars would drink.
social.author: Dane Marshall

social.quote: If wishes were horses, beggars would ride.
social.author: John Ray

social.quote: Few have all they need, none all they wish.
social.author: Robert Southwell

social.quote: Nice guys finish last.
social.author: Leo Durocher

social.quote: Every time a friend succeeds, I die a little.
social.author: Gore Vidal

social.quote: You always pass failure on the way to success.
social.author: Mickey Rooney

social.quote: Fear of losing is what makes competitors so great. Show me a gracious loser and I'll show you a permanent loser.
social.author: O. J. Simpson

social.quote: The mere wit is only a human bauble. He is to life what bells are to horses-not expected to draw the load, but only to jingle while the horses draw.
social.author: Henry Ward Beecher

social.quote: Humorous persons have pleasant mouths turned up at the corners... But the mouth of a merely witty man is hard and sour until the moment of its discharge.
social.author: Charles S. Brooks

social.quote: A man must have a good share of wit himself to endure a great share in another.
social.author: Lord Chesterfield

social.quote: Wit is so shining a quality that everybody admires it; most people aim at it, all people fear it, and few love it unless in themselves.
social.author: Lord Chesterfield

social.quote: The more wit we have, the less satisfied we are with it.
social.author: Jean Le Rond D'Alembert

social.quote: Men never think their fortune too great, nor their wit too little.
social.author: Thomas Fuller

social.quote: Many get the repute of being witty but thereby lose the credit of being sensible. Jest has its little hour, seriousness should have all the rest.
social.author: Baltasar Gracian

social.quote: Wit is the salt of conversation, not the food.
social.author: William Hazlitt

social.quote: Impertinent wits are a kind of insect which are in everybody's way and plentiful in all countries.
social.author: Jean de La Bruyere

social.quote: True wit, to every man, is that which falls on another.
social.author: Walter Savage Landor

social.quote: W'en you see a man in woe, Walk right up and say 'hullo'; Say "hullo" and "how d'ye do. How's the world a-usin' you?"
social.author: Sam Walter Foss

social.quote: Out of my great woe I make my little song.
social.author: Heinrich Heine

social.quote: Alas! by some degree of woe we every bliss must gain.
social.author: Lord Lyttleton

social.quote: As night to stars, woe lustre gives to man.
social.author: Edward Young

social.quote: When a woman is talking to you, listen to what she says with her eyes.
social.author: Victor Hugo

social.quote: A lady is one who never shows her underwear unintentionally.
social.author: Lillian Day

social.quote: I'm not denyin' the women are foolish: God Almighty made 'em to match the men.
social.author: George Eliot

social.quote: A sufficient measure of civilization is the influence of good women.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: When you educate a man you educate an individual; when you educate a woman you educate a whole family.
social.author: Dr. Charles D. McIver

social.quote: Without woman the beginning of our life would be helpless, the middle without pleasure, and the end void of consolation.
social.author: Victor de Jouy

social.quote: Some women'll stay in a man's memory if they once walked down a street.
social.author: Rudyard Kipling

social.quote: I've always found it much more dangerous to fool with a man's mistress than his wife.
social.author: Harold Robbins

social.quote: If you get a fine woman, you get the finest thing on earth.
social.author: Elaine Francis Burton

social.quote: Woman, I hold, is the personification of self-sacrifice, but unfortunately today she does not realize what a tremendous advantage she has over man. As Tolstoy used to say, they are laboring under the hypnotic influence of man. If they would realize the strength of non-violence they would not consent to be called the weaker sex.
social.author: Mahatma Gandhi

social.quote: And the beauty of a woman, with passing years only grows!
social.author: Audrey Hepburn

social.quote: There's a great woman behind every idiot.
social.author: John Lennon

social.quote: I always say it was great for God to send his only son, but I'm waiting for him to send his only daughter. Then things will really be great.
social.author: Candace Pert

social.quote: Women are the most powerful magnet in the universe; all men are cheap metal.
social.author: Larry Miller

social.quote: Women have simple tastes. They can get pleasure out of the conversation of children in arms and men in love.
social.author: H. L. Mencken

social.quote: Nature has given women so much power that the law has very wisely given them little.
social.author: Samuel Johnson

social.quote: Some of us are becoming the men we wanted to marry.
social.author: Gloria Steinem

social.quote: A woman will always sacrifice herself if you give her the opportunity. It is her favorite form of self-indulgence.
social.author: W. Somerset Maugham

social.quote: The trouble with some women is that they get all excited about nothing and then marry him.
social.author: Cher

social.quote: That's the nature of women, not to love when we love them, and to love when we love them not.
social.author: Miguel de Cervantes

social.quote: Men love to wonder, and that is the seed of science.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: Wonder is the basis of worship.
social.author: Thomas Carlyle

social.quote: Wherever life takes us, there are always moments of wonder.
social.author: Jimmy Carter

social.quote: Men love to wonder, and that is the seed of our science.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: What happens to the hopes and dreams and wonder with which every child is born? Can it be that in working so hard to prepare them for their future roles in society, we are neglecting to offer a vision of their place in the universe?
social.author: Jean Grasso Fitzpatrick

social.quote: There are certain scenes that would awe an atheist into belief without the help of any other argument.
social.author: Thomas Gray

social.quote: If the stars should appear one night in a thousand years, how would men believe and adore!
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: All wonder is the effect of novelty on ignorance.
social.author: Samuel Johnson

social.quote: Our brains are no longer conditioned for reverence and awe. We cannot imagine a Second Coming that would not be cut down to size by the televised evening news, or a Last Judgment not subject to pages of holier-than-thou second-guessing in The New York Review of Books.
social.author: John Updike

social.quote: After fifteen minutes nobody looks at a rainbow.
social.author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

social.quote: The world will never starve for want of wonders.
social.author: G. K. Chesterton

social.quote: The more we learn about the wonders of our universe, the more clearly we are going to perceive the hand of God.
social.author: Frank Borman

social.quote: In six pages, I can't even say "Hello."
social.author: James Michener

social.quote: Writers talk too much.
social.author: Lillian Hellman

social.quote: First coffee. Then a bowel movement. Then the muse joins me.
social.author: Gore Vidal

social.quote: Writers should be read - but neither seen nor heard.
social.author: Daphne du Maurier

social.quote: The first thing to look out for after your first big success are drugs and screenplays.
social.author: Richard Price

social.quote: You are not saved by works; you are saved to work.
social.author: Lewis Timberlake

social.quote: Your actions in passing, pass not away, for every good work is a grain of seed for eternal life.
social.author: Saint Bernard of Clairvaux

social.quote: Every man is the son of his own works.
social.author: Miguel de Cervantes

social.quote: You never will be saved by works; but let us tell you most solemnly that you never will be saved without works.
social.author: T. L. Cuyler

social.quote: Without knowing the force of words, it is impossible to know men.
social.author: Confucius

social.quote: The return from your work must be the satisfaction which that work brings you and the world's need of that work. With this, life is heaven, or as near heaven as you can get. Without this-with work which you despise, which bores you and which the world does not need-this life is hell.
social.author: W. E. B. Du Bois

social.quote: To deny a man a job is to say that a man has no right to exist.
social.author: Martin Luther King, Jr.

social.quote: No race can prosper till it learns that there is as much dignity in tilling a field as in writing a poem.
social.author: Booker T. Washington

social.quote: All words are pegs to hang ideas on.
social.author: Henry Ward Beecher

social.quote: It need hardly be said that shortness is a merit in words.
social.author: H. W. Fowler

social.quote: Those who run to long words are mainly the unskillful and tasteless; they confuse pomposity with dignity, flaccidity with ease, and bulk with force.
social.author: H. W. Fowler

social.quote: Words form the thread on which we string our experiences.
social.author: Aldous Huxley

social.quote: Words not only affect us temporarily; they change us, they socialize or unsocialize us.
social.author: David Riesman

social.quote: My father still reads the dictionary every day. He says your life depends on your power to master words.
social.author: Arthur Scargill

social.quote: His brow is wet with honest sweat, He earns whate'er he can, And looks the whole world in the face, For he owes not any man.
social.author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

social.quote: Slave of the wheel of labor, what to him Are Plato and the swing of Pleiades?
social.author: Edwin Markham

social.quote: When white-collar people get jobs, they sell not only their time and energy, but their personalities as well. They sell by the week, or month, their smiles and their kindly gestures, and they must practice that prompt repression of resentment and aggression.
social.author: C. Wright Mills

social.quote: The really efficient laborer will be found not to crowd his day with work, but will saunter to his task surrounded by a wide halo of ease and leisure.
social.author: Henry David Thoreau

social.quote: If you do things by the job, you are perpetually driven: the hours are scourges. If you work by the hour, you gently sail on the stream of Time, which is always bearing you on to the haven of Pay, whether you make any effort, or not.
social.author: Charles Dudley Warner

social.quote: They hurt themselves that wrong others.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: He who wrongs one threatens many.
social.author: Publilius Syrus

social.quote: A career is wonderful, but you can't curl up with a career on a cold night.
social.author: Marilyn Monroe

social.quote: ... one does people the best service by giving them some elevating work to do and thus indirectly elevating them.
social.author: Albert Einstein

social.quote: If I had eight hours to chop down a tree, I'd spend six sharpening my ax.
social.author: Abraham Lincoln

social.quote: In our zeal to make a living we have forgotten to make a life.
social.author: Lewis Timberlake

social.quote: Work without love is slavery.
social.author: Mother Teresa

social.quote: Integrate what you believe into every single area of your life. Take your heart to work and ask the most and best of everybody else. Don't let your special character and values, the secret that you know and no one else does, the truth-don't let that get swallowed up by the great chewing complacency.
social.author: Meryl Streep

social.quote: Work spares us from three evils: boredom, vice, and need.
social.author: Voltaire

social.quote: If the building of a bridge does not enrich the awareness of those who work on it, then that bridge ought not to be built.
social.author: Frantz Fanon

social.quote: No man is born into the world whose work is not born with him.
social.author: Anonymous

social.quote: How do I work? I grope.
social.author: Albert Einstein

social.quote: The world is a bride of surpassing beauty-but remember that this maiden is never bound to anyone.
social.author: Hafiz

social.quote: The world is a comedy to those that think; a tragedy to those that feel.
social.author: Horace Walpole

social.quote: Do not expect too much of the end of the world.
social.author: Stanislaw J. Lec

social.quote: To me it seems as if when God conceived the world, that was Poetry; He formed it, and that was Sculpture; He colored it, and that was Painting; He peopled it with living beings, and that was the grand, divine, eternal Drama.
social.author: Charlotte Cushman

social.quote: It's a funny old world-a man's lucky if he gets out of it alive.
social.author: W. C. Fields

social.quote: If you think the world is all wrong, remember that it contains people like you.
social.author: Mahatma Gandhi

social.quote: This world is a comedy to those that think, a tragedy to those that feel.
social.author: Horace Walpole

social.quote: For in and out, above, about, below, 'Tis nothing but a Magic Shadow-show, Played in a Box whose Candle is the Sun, Round which we Phantom Figures come and go.
social.author: Omar Khayyam

social.quote: No cradle for an emperor's child was ever prepared with so much magnificence as this world has been made for man. But it is only his cradle.
social.author: Henry Ward Beecher

social.quote: To see a World in a Grain of Sand, And a Heaven in a Wild Flower, Hold Infinity in the palm of your hand, And Eternity in an hour.
social.author: William Blake

social.quote: When I look back on all these worries I remember the story of the old man who said on his deathbed that he had a lot of trouble in his life, most of which never happened.
social.author: Winston Churchill

social.quote: Worry is interest paid on trouble before it falls due.
social.author: Dean W. R. Inge

social.quote: Rule number one is, don't sweat the small stuff. Rule number two is, it's all small stuff.
social.author: Robert Eliot

social.quote: How much pain have cost us the evils which never happened.
social.author: Thomas Jefferson

social.quote: A man gets on a train with his little boy, and gives the conductor only one ticket. 'How old's your kid?' the conductor says, and the father says, 'He's four years old.' 'He looks at least twelve to me,' says the conductor. And the father says, 'Can I help it if he worries?'
social.author: Robert Benchley

social.quote: I highly recommend worrying. It is much more effective than dieting.
social.author: William Powell

social.quote: It ain't no use putting up your umbrella till it rains.
social.author: Alice Caldwell Rice

social.quote: Worrying is the most natural and spontaneous of all human functions. It is time to acknowledge this, perhaps even to learn to do it better.
social.author: Lewis Thomas

social.quote: A person must try to worry about things that aren't important so he won't worry too much about things that are.
social.author: Jack Smith

social.quote: Niche worrying is a means of conveniently organizing one's paranoia. It's concentrating on a specific fear or phobia at an appropriate time, like focusing on getting legionnaires' disease from inhaling steam containing Legionella pneumophilia bacteria while taking a shower at the gym.
social.author: Cameron Tuttle

social.quote: An African writer who really wants to interpret the African scene has to write in three dimensions at once. There is the private life, the social life, and what you may call the supernatural.
social.author: Elechi Amadi

social.quote: I have never thought of my life as divided between poetry and politics.
social.author: Pablo Neruda

social.quote: It is Sunday, mid-morning-Sunday in the living room, Sunday in the kitchen, Sunday in the woodshed, Sunday down the road in the village: I hear the bells, calling me to share God's grace.
social.author: E. B. White

social.quote: A writer should have another lifetime to see whether he is appreciated.
social.author: Jorge Luis Borges

social.quote: What a writer wants to do is not what he does.
social.author: Jorge Luis Borges

social.quote: The history of catastrophe requires such a literature to hold a broken mirror up to broken nature.
social.author: Edward Kamau Brathwaite

social.quote: The typewriter separated me from a deeper intimacy with poetry, and my hand brought me closer to that intimacy again.
social.author: Pablo Neruda

social.quote: Literature must be an analysis of experience and a synthesis of the findings into a unity.
social.author: Rebecca West

social.quote: Heathen, n. A benighted creature who has the folly to worship something that he can see and feel.
social.author: Ambrose Bierce

social.quote: Many infidels have maintained that Ignorance is the mother of Devotion.
social.author: James Boswell

social.quote: As a single leaf turns not yellow but with the silent knowledge of the whole tree, so the wrong-doer cannot do wrong without the hidden will of you all.
social.author: Kahlil Gibran

social.quote: The act of evil breeds others to follow, young sins in its own likeness.
social.author: Aeschylus

social.quote: The sinner sins against himself; the wrongdoer wrongs himself, becoming the worse by his own action.
social.author: Marcus Aurelius

social.quote: If once a man indulges himself in murder, very soon he comes to think little of robbing; and from robbing he comes next to drinking and Sabbath-breaking, and from that to incivility and procrastination.
social.author: Thomas De Quincey

social.quote: Throughout our life, our worst weaknesses and meannesses are usually committed for the sake of the people whom we most despise.
social.author: Charles Dickens

social.quote: You cannot do wrong without suffering wrong.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: For a wrongdoer to be undetected is difficult; and for him to have confidence that his concealment will continue is impossible.
social.author: Epicurus

social.quote: If one must do a wrong, it's best to do it pursuing power-otherwise, let's have virtue.
social.author: Euripides

social.quote: A small demerit extinguishes a long service.
social.author: Thomas Fuller

social.quote: You start by writing to live. You end by writing so as not to die.
social.author: Carlos Fuentes

social.quote: I think you must remember that a writer is a simple-minded person to begin with and go on that basis. He's not a great mind, he's not a great thinker, he's not a great philosopher, he's a story-teller.
social.author: Erskine Caldwell

social.quote: I detest professional anythings but particularly professional writers. Most of them today are just garbage collectors.
social.author: Cleveland Amory

social.quote: He that writes to himself writes to an eternal public.
social.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

social.quote: Enduring fame is promised only to those writers who can offer to successive generations a substance constantly renewed; for every generation arrives upon the scene with its own particular hunger.
social.author: Andre Gide

social.quote: The pen is a formidable weapon, but a man can kill himself with it a great deal more easily than he can other people.
social.author: George Dennison Prentice

social.quote: I have just been refining the room in which I sit, yet I sometimes doubt that a writer should refine or improve his workroom by so much as a dictionary: one thing leads to another and the first thing you know he has a stuffed chair and is fast asleep in it.
social.author: E. B. White

social.quote: In the nature of things, a person engaged in the flimsy business of expressing himself on paper is dependent on the large general privilege of being heard. Any intimation that this privilege may be revoked throws a writer into panic.
social.author: E. B. White

social.quote: The essayist is a self-liberated man, sustained by the childish belief that everything he thinks about, everything that happens to him, is of general interest.
social.author: E. B. White

social.quote: The great play is yet unwritten; the great novel beats with futile hands against the portals of my brain.
social.author: Thomas Wolfe

social.quote: If you want to write ... you must lurk in libraries and climb the stacks like ladders to sniff books like perfumes and wear books like hats upon your crazy heads.
social.author: Ray Bradbury

social.quote: Seventeen publishers rejected the manuscript, at which time we knew we had something pretty hot.
social.author: Kinky Friedman

social.quote: My ideal job? Landlord of a bordello! The company's good and the mornings are quiet, which is the best time to write.
social.author: William Faulkner

social.quote: If you asked someone, 'Can you play the violin?' and he says, 'I don't know, I have not tried, perhaps I can,' you laugh at him. Whereas about writing, people always say: 'I don't know, I have not tried,' as though one had only to try and one would become a writer.
social.author: Leo Tolstoy

social.quote: Most people who seek attention and regard by announcing that they're writing a novel are actually so devoid of narrative talent that they can't hold the attention of a dinner table for thirty seconds, even with a dirty joke.
social.author: Paul Fussell

social.quote: Writing is the hardest way of earning a living, with the possible exception of wrestling alligators.
social.author: Olin Miller

social.quote: I always start a book for money. If you're married five times you have to.
social.author: Norman Mailer

social.quote: A man's got to take a lot of punishment to write a really funny book.
social.author: Ernest Hemingway

social.quote: The only advice I have to give a young novelist is to fuck a really good agent.
social.author: John Cheever

social.quote: At the drabber moments of my life (swilling some excrement from the steps, for instance, or rooting with a bent coat-hanger down a blocked sink) thoughts occur like 'I bet Tom Stoppard doesn't have to do this' or There is no doubt David Hare would have deputed this to an underling'.
social.author: Alan Bennett

social.quote: Oaks may fall when reeds stand the storm.
social.author: Thomas Fuller

social.quote: I bend but do not break.
social.author: Jean de La Fontaine

social.quote: Bowed down then preserved; Bent then straight; Hollow then full; Worn then new; A little then benefited; A lot then perplexed.
social.author: Lao-tzu

social.quote: A storm breaks trees. It only bends grass.
social.author: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn

social.quote: Yield to God.
social.author: Virgil

social.quote: Great ideas have a very short shelf life.
social.author: John M. Shanahan

social.quote: Reality is the other persons idea of how things should be.
social.author: John M. Shanahan

social.quote: The art of being wise is the art of knowing what to overlook.
social.author: William James

social.quote: To be ignorant of one's ignorance is the malady of the ignorant.
social.author: Bronson Alcott

social.quote: I am not young enough to know everything.
social.author: Oscar Wilde

social.quote: Nothing that is worth knowing can be taught.
social.author: Oscar Wilde

social.quote: It's bad taste to be wise all the time, like being at a perpetual funeral.
social.author: D. H. Lawrence

social.quote: The mind's direction is more important than its progress.
social.author: Joseph Joubert

social.quote: All intelligent thoughts have already been thought; what is necessary is only to try to think them again.
social.author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

social.quote: An invasion of armies can be resisted, but not an idea whose time has come.
social.author: Victor Hugo

social.quote: Young men think old men are fools; but old men know young men are fools.
social.author: George Chapman

social.quote: Believe me, all evil comes from the old. They grow fat on ideas and young men die of them.
social.author: Jean Anouilh

social.quote: If age, which is certainly Just as wicked as youth, look any wiser, It is only that youth is still able to believe It will get away with anything, while age Knows only too well that it has got away with nothing.
social.author: W. H. Auden

social.quote: The old repeat themselves and the young have nothing to say The boredom is mutual.
social.author: Jacques Bainville

social.quote: The young fancy that their follies are mistaken by the old for happiness. The old fancy that their gravity is mistaken by the young for wisdom.
social.author: Charles Caleb Colton

social.quote: A youth without fire is followed by an old age without experience.
social.author: Charles Caleb Colton

social.quote: In youth the life of reason is not in itself sufficient; afterwards the life of emotion, except for short periods, becomes unbearable.
social.author: Cyril Connolly

social.quote: Old hands soil, it seems, what they caress; but they too have their beauty when they are joined in prayer. Young hands are made for caresses and the sheathing of love; it is a pity to make them join too soon.
social.author: Andre Gide

social.quote: Old people are a kind of monsters to little folks; mild manifestations of the terrible, it may be, but still, with their white locks and ridged and grooved features, which those horrid little eyes exhaust of their details like so many microscopes, not exactly what human beings ought to be.
social.author: Oliver Wendell Holmes

social.quote: Age looks with anger on the temerity of youth, and youth with contempt on the scrupulosity of age.
social.author: Samuel Johnson

social.quote: Few, if any, survive their teens. Most surrender to the vague but murderous pressure of adult conformity.
social.author: Maya Angelou

social.quote: Money is sullen And wisdom is sly, But youth is the pollen That blows through the sky And does not ask why.
social.author: Stephen Vincent Benet

social.quote: It is better to waste one's youth than to do nothing with it at all.
social.author: Georges Courteline

social.quote: While we are young the idea of death or failure is intolerable to us; even the possibility of ridicule we cannot bear.
social.author: Isak Dinesen

social.quote: Adolescence can be a time of turmoil and turbulence, of stress and storm. Rebellion against authority and against convention is to be expected and tolerated for the sake of learning and growth.
social.author: Haim G. Ginott

social.quote: Alas, that Spring should vanish with the Rose! That Youths sweet-scented Manuscript should close!
social.author: Omar Khayyam

social.quote: I'm not young enough to know everything.
social.author: J. M. Barrie

social.quote: It takes a long time to become young.
social.author: Pablo Picasso

social.quote: Youth is something very new: twenty years ago no one mentioned it.
social.author: Coco Chanel

social.quote: Zen does not confuse spirituality with thinking about God while one is peeling potatoes. Zen spirituality is just to peel the potatoes.
social.author: Alan W. Watts

social.quote: Zen is the unsymbolization of the world.
social.author: R. H. Blyth

social.quote: Zeal without knowledge is fire without light.
social.author: Thomas Fuller

social.quote: Zeal will do more than knowledge.
social.author: William Hazlitt

social.quote: Let a man in a garret but burn with enough intensity and he will set fire to the world.
social.author: Antoine de Saint-Exupery

social.quote: Press bravely onward! not in vain Your generous trust in human-kind; The good which bloodshed could not gain Your peaceful zeal shall find.
social.author: John Greenleaf Whittier

social.quote: Through zeal, knowledge is gotten; through lack of zeal, knowledge is lost.
social.author: Buddha
